Recyclable and dual active catalyst of copper nanocluster-bound graphitic carbon nitride for the photo-induced synthesis of arylsulfones Jinseok Lee a 1 Seunghwan An b 1 Mihee Jang b Hyun Min Jung a ⁎ Sunwoo Lee b ⁎ a Department of Applied Chemistry and Department of Energy Engineering Convergence, Kumoh National Institute of Technology, Gumi 39177, Republic of Korea Department of Applied Chemistry and Department of Energy Engineering Convergence Kumoh National Institute of Technology Gumi 39177 Republic of Korea aDepartment of Applied Chemistry and Department of Energy Engineering Convergence, Kumoh National Institute of Technology, Gumi, 39177, Republic of Korea b Department of Chemistry, Chonnam National University, Gwangju 61186, Republic of Korea Department of Chemistry Chonnam National University Gwangju 61186 Republic of Korea bDepartment of Chemistry, Chonnam National University, Gwangju, 61186 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors are equally contributed. A photocatalytic system of Cu(0) nanocluster-bound graphitic carbon nitride (Cu(0)-g-C3N4) was developed for three-component arylsulfonylation reactions. The Cu(0)-g-C3N4 nanocomposite has a structure in which 2–5 nm metallic Cu nanoclusters are anchored on the surface of g-C3N4 nanosheets. The Cu(0) clusters were synthesized by reducing Cu2+ ions with ascorbic acid in the presence of g-C3N4 nanosheets. Cu(0)-g-C3N4 was designed to exhibit dual catalytic activity involving the transfer of photo-induced electrons from g-C3N4 to Cu(0) for the reduction of arylhalides, while the holes in g-C3N4 oxidize the sulfur dioxide anion. The structure of the catalyst was confirmed by electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The well-defined, air-stable Cu(0)-g-C3N4 catalyst effectively promotes the sulfonylation of aryl iodides, thiourea dioxide, and electrophiles to afford the corresponding arylsulfonyl compounds in moderate to good yields. The reusability of the catalyst was also evaluated, and it could be reused up to ten times in arylsulfonylation without the loss of its activity. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Data availability All data is available in Supporting Information file. 1 Introduction Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) has attracted attention for various applications owing to its unique photoelectronic properties, excellent thermal and chemical stabilities, and easy, ecofriendly, and low-cost manufacturing process. Among its various characteristics, its bandgap of 2.7 eV and nitrogen-rich two-dimensional structure render it a promising metal-free photocatalyst [1]. However, pure bulk g-C3N4 does not have high photocatalytic activity owing to slow carrier transportation, low light absorption, rapid recombination of excitons, and low specific surface area. Therefore, to improve the photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4, nanosheet formation through the exfoliation of bulk g-C3N4 or functionalization through metal doping and heterojunction formation have been explored, and high catalytic activities have been realized [2]. Recently, g-C3N4 was applied as a photocatalyst in hydrogen evolution [3] and oxygen evolution reactions [4], CO2 reduction [5], photodegradation [6], bacterial disinfection [7], and organic synthesis [8]. For these applications, various catalytic metal atoms were loaded on the surface of g-C3N4 nanosheets for achieving improved catalytic activity in organic reactions (Scheme 1 a). Among various metals, Cu was found to be suitable for redox reactions, and it was loaded onto g-C3N4 and applied in coupling reactions. N-arylation was effectively performed on Cu/g-C3N4 as the catalyst and O-arylation and homo cross-coupling were performed using mesoporous g-C3N4 [9,10]. However, in the various catalytic applications of Cu/g-C3N4 nanocomposites, g-C3N4 was used as a support for improving the catalytic activity of Cu nanoparticles, and there are a few reports on a catalytic pathway involving the combined activities of Cu and g-C3N4 [11]. In particular, the unique photocatalytic activity of g-C3N4 has rarely been observed in coupling reactions catalyzed by Cu/g-C3N4. In a previous study, the homocoupling of benzylamine through a photocatalytic reaction over Cu/g-C3N4 was conducted, however, the reaction was mediated by hydroxyl radicals generated from water [12]. In this study, we prepared Cu nanocluster-loaded g-C3N4 (Cu(0)-g-C3N4) and applied it in arylsulfone synthesis by a coupling reaction that directly involves the photoredox phenomenon. It was also noted that the well-designed Cu(0)-g-C3N4 as a heterogeneous catalyst could be a way to overcome the situation in which a high ratio of transition metal catalysts are used in general coupling reactions, and additional processes are required for the removal and separation of catalysts. Arylsulfones are one of the most important functional groups in organic synthesis because they are not only found in many marketed drugs but also have significant relevance in material chemistry as well as polymer preparation [13]. Various approaches have been developed for the preparation of sulfones with an aryl moiety, and they are widely applied in the construction of various arylsulfones. Among them, the direct coupling reaction between an active arylsulfonyl compound and carbon-based coupling partners is the most straightforward method. Arylsulfonyl chlorides [14], arylsulfinic acids [15], arylsulfinates [16], and arylsulfonyl hydrazides [17] are generally used as arylsulfonyl sources and are reacted with various counterparts such as CH-activated arenes [18], alkynes [19], alkenes [20], aryl halides [21], aryl boronic acids [22], and aryl diazonium salts [23]. However, all these cases require the synthesis of arylated sulfone moieties, which is inconvenient. Moreover, only one example of the recyclable heterogeneous catalytic system was reported. As an alternative method, three-component arylsulfonylation reactions using sulfur dioxide surrogates have recently gained significant momentum because of the easy accessibility and wide variety of coupling partners (Scheme 1b) [24]. A variety of synthetic methods have been developed using transition metal catalysts, in addition, visible-light mediated reactions have also been conducted to obtain the desired products in good yields [25]. Although organic catalysts as well as transition metal catalysts have exhibited good activities as photoredox catalysts under light-emitting diode (LED) irradiation conditions, there are limitations in terms of reusability as well as the cost of the process because they are all homogeneous catalysts. Although organic catalysts as well as transition metal catalysts have exhibited good activities as photoredox catalysts under light-emitting diode (LED) irradiation conditions, there are limitations in terms of reusability as well as the cost of the process because they are all homogeneous catalysts. To the best of our knowledge, a heterogeneous photoredox catalytic system has never been employed in the three-component arylsulfonylation reaction. Therefore, the development of a reusable catalyst system considering economic aspects is highly demanded. Herein, we demonstrate the dual catalytic pathway of Cu(0)-g-C3N4, which catalyzes arylsulfonylation via a photoredox process. g-C3N4 has a bandgap of 2.7 eV and generates holes and electrons when irradiated with visible light. The photogenerated electrons can move rapidly to the conducting band of Cu(0) to induce the reduction reaction, while the holes in g-C3N4 participate in the oxidation reaction. In this article, we present the preparation of Cu(0)-g-C3N4 with the most suitable structure for photoredox reactions and the results of three-component aryl sulfonylation reactions conducted via the dual catalytic pathway, in which both the photogenerated holes and electrons participate. In addition, we envisioned that the reusable heterogeneous catalytic system was successfully operated in the coupling reaction (Scheme 1c). 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and structural analysis of Cu(0)-g-C3N4 Copper-bound g-C3N4 can be designed in various shapes with different oxidation states of copper. In this study, we planned to prepare a Cu(0)-g-C3N4 nanocomposite in which copper particles are attached to the surface of g-C3N4 nanosheets in Cu(0) state and have a size of several nanometers. For this, we first exfoliated a powder of bulk g-C3N4 synthesized from melamine via a high-temperature annealing method (see Supplementary material for details) into nanosheets through ultrasonication. In the general method of introducing a metal ion, metal ions of interest are added during the preparation of bulk g-C3N4, resulting in the coordination of the metal ion in the large pores of g-C3N4 [26]. However, this method is not suitable for the uniform binding of nanosized metallic copper to g-C3N4, as desired. Therefore, in this work, uniform Cu(0) particles of 2–5 nm sizes were synthesized on g-C3N4 nanosheets by reducing Cu2+ ions with ascorbic acid in the presence of them (Scheme 2 ). The structure and morphology of Cu(0)-g-C3N4 were investigated through transmission electron microscopy (TEM), which confirmed the attachment of Cu(0) in the nanocluster state to the entire g-C3N4 nanosheet surface (Fig. 1 (b)). High-magnification observations through scanning TEM (STEM) revealed that Cu(0) particles with sizes in the range of 2–5 nm were distributed on the nanosheet surface, and each cluster had a clear boundary and was separated by a distance of several nanometers from its nearest neighbors (Fig. 1(c)). The size distribution of Cu(0) nanocluster was estimated by TEM image (Fig. 1(c)), and the average size was confirmed to be about 3.5 nm. Considering that the size of the basic g-C3N4 unit composed of (C3N4)6 is 1.3 nm according to molecular modeling, each Cu(0) particle was located on approximately 2–3 basic units. In addition, the thickness of the samples was measured using a thickness measuring system. The g-C3N4 nanosheets exhibited 1.5 nm thickness and Cu(0)-g-C3N4 was measured as 1.6 – 4.7 nm thickness, indicating that Cu(0)-g-C3N4 maintained original nanosheet shape during Cu bounding process. In the mapping image of copper obtained through energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), the distribution of Cu(0) particles was clearly identified, and the Cu distribution in the sample was consistent with that observed in the STEM image (Fig. 1(d)). This structure can play an important role in efficient photocatalytic reactions. In the intended photoredox reaction, exciton formation in g-C3N4 nanosheets, the transfer of the photogenerated electrons and holes, and their participation in the reaction are important. However, if Cu(0) completely covers the entire surface of g-C3N4 nanosheets or undergoes clustering to form islands that are sparsely distributed on g-C3N4 nanosheets, the efficiency of the reaction decreases because the electrons generated in g-C3N4 nanosheets are separated and transferred to Cu(0) at a low rate. Therefore, a uniform distribution and small interparticle distances of nanoscale Cu(0) particles are required to shorten the pathway and accelerate the electron transfer from g-C3N4 nanosheets to Cu(0), and thereby lower the recombination of the excitons and thus increase the efficiency of their participation in the reaction. The formation of 3.5 nm Cu(0) clusters on the g-C3N4 nanosheets surface with interparticle gaps of several nanometers would be highly favorable for dual photocatalytic reactions, in which both the generated electrons and holes participate in appropriate reactions (Fig. 2 ). Moreover, considering that the oxidation state of copper affects the three-component arylsulfonylation, it is important to form metallic copper nanoclusters for the transfer of electrons from g-C3N4 nanosheets to Cu(0). The electrons generated in g-C3N4 nanosheets are expected to move freely to the conducting band of metallic copper. In this state, electrons participate in the generation of aryl radicals from aryl halide molecules over the surface of the Cu(0) particle. Meanwhile, the hole in g-C3N4 nanosheets accepts an electron from sulfur dioxide anion (SO2 2–) to generate a sulfur dioxide radical anion. The reaction pathway for the formation of aryl sulfonate anion from the thiourea dioxide is not clear under this photo reaction conditions. However, Wu and Li proposed that sulfur dioxide radical anion was formed from SO2 2– and reacted with aryl radical to give arylsulfonate anion [26a]. Thus, all photo-induced excitons in Cu(0)-g-C3N4 participate in the dual catalytic pathway, in which an appropriate reaction proceeds at each catalytic site, resulting in three-component aryl sulfonylation. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of Cu(0)-g-C3N4 (Fig. 3 a) confirmed that the Cu species formed on the surface of g-C3N4 nanosheets were in the metallic state. Strong and clear diffraction peaks of (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes of Cu(0) were identified (JCPDS #: 04–0836) along with the diffraction peak of the (002) plane of g-C3N4 nanosheets (JCPDS #: 87–1526). Although the Cu(0) clusters were formed with a very small size of 2–5 nm, the Cu atoms were aligned and stacked well, and the nanoclusters were highly crystalline. In particular, the XRD pattern of Cu(0)-g-C3N4 did not exhibit any peaks of the oxidized forms of Cu, viz., Cu2O and CuO, owing to the slow reduction of Cu2+ by ascorbic acid on the surface of g-C3N4 nanosheets without high-temperature treatment for the formation of Cu(0) particles. The absence of copper oxides, which could form heterojunctions at the Cu(0) interface, is critical for free electron transfer from g-C3N4 nanosheets to the Cu(0) nanoclusters. The various states of nitrogen in g-C3N4 nanosheets were identified by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The XPS profile of Cu(0)-g-C3N4 (Fig. 3d) exhibited peaks attributable to oxidized N (402.7 eV), graphitic N (399.6 eV), pyrrolic N (397.9 eV), and pyridinic N (396.5 eV). In particular, the peak observed at 397.4 eV for Cu-N confirmed the anchoring of Cu particles on the g-C3N4 surface. The state of Cu could be confirmed by directly observing the Cu 2P binding energy: Cu(0)-g-C3N4 before the catalytic reaction was observed with binding energies of the Cu(0) state of 950.7 eV and 930.8 eV. In this state, it can be seen that the binding energy around 940 eV, which appears in Cu2+ [27], was not observed (Fig. 3(e)). After catalytic arylsulfonylation of Cu(0)-g-C3N4 in this state, the binding energy by Cu(0) was observed without significant change, and the peak caused by Cu2+ at 942.1 eV slightly grew with relatively much low intensity (Fig. 3(f)), indicating that Cu(0)-g-C3N4 has the high stability even when used under catalytic reaction conditions. The morphology and Cu state of Cu(0)-g- C3N4 after recovery from the reaction were additionally confirmed through TEM and XRD, and showed no significant change from the pre-reaction state (Fig. S1). In TEM, the shape of Cu particles attached to the g-C3N4 nanosheet was maintained without aggregation or desorption, and the particle size showed no change. Unlike XPS, where slight oxidation was observed, the changed Cu state did not appear in XRD, and the relative intensity with g-C3N4 was maintained. The copper content in Cu(0)-g-C3N4 was determined to be 34.4% through inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). Further, the copper content of a Cu2O-g-C3N4 nanocomposite prepared for comparative reactions was 18.9%. Based on these copper contents, the amount of the catalyst used in aryl sulfonylation reactions was adjusted. The change in the Cu content of Cu(0)-g-C3N4 was measured by ICP-OES again for the samples recovered from the reaction solution after 10th catalysis reactions, and a value of 33%(±3%) was obtained from this. The stability of Cu-bound g-C3N4 was estimated by the result without desorption of Cu from g-C3N4 or leaching out even in repeated reactions. In additionally, electron spin resonance (ESR) spectrum (Fig. 3b) provided further information about Cu(0)-g-C3N4. For g-C3N4, paramagnetic signal with a g value of 2.00 due to unpaired electrons was shown [28]. Compared to the original g-C3N4, Cu(0)-g-C3N4 showed a signal with a g value of 2.08, which is presumed to be caused by Cu2+ [11]. From the fact that Cu2+species were not observed in XRD and XPS (Fig. 3a, 3e), it appears that Cu2+was derived from very small fraction of the original Cu(0) cluster. Since the signal by Cu2+appeared relatively higher intensity, it was difficult to confirm the change of the signal by the original g-C3N4, which was possibly affected by Cu(0) cluster on change of the concentration of unpaired electrons. 2.2 Photocatalyzed three-component arylsulfonylation Using Cu(0)-g-C3N4 as the catalyst, a three-component coupling reaction for arylsulfone synthesis was studied. 4-Iodoacetophenone, thiourea dioxide, and tert‑butyl 2-bromoacetate were chosen as standard substrates, and many experiments were conducted for the optimization of the reaction conditions. The results are summarized in Table 1 . The optimized reaction conditions are as follows: first, 1a and thiourea dioxide were reacted in the presence of 5 mol% Cu(0)-g-C3N4 in dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) containing NaOH (4 equiv.) at 25 °C for 24 h under blue LED irradiation, and then, the resulting mixture was treated with tert‑butyl 2-bromoacetate at 25 °C for 3 h to obtain 2a in 72% yield (entry 1). When Na2CO3 and K2CO3 were used as the base instead of NaOH, the desired product was formed in low yields (entries 2 and 3). The reaction conducted with Cs2CO3 as the base resulted in 62% yield of 2a (entry 4). The addition of tetrabutylammonium chloride (TBACl) or tetrabutylammonium iodide (TBAI) as a phase transfer reagent did not provide satisfactory results (entries 5 and 6). When the reaction was conducted in MeOH or EtOH as the solvent, 2a was formed in 31 or 13% yield, respectively (entries 7 and 8). However, reactions in other solvents such as N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA), MeCN, toluene, and tetrahydrofuran (THF) did not lead to the desired product (entry 9). K2S2O5, Na2S2O5, and 1,4-Diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane bis(sulfur dioxide) adduct (DABSO), which are known as sulfur dioxide surrogates, did not show any activity in this transformation (entry 10). Under the optimized conditions, various aryl iodides were reacted with thiourea dioxide and tert‑butyl 2-bromoacetate. The results are summarized in Scheme 3 . As expected, 4-iodoacetophenone produced 2a with 72% isolated yield. 4-Iodobenzaldehyde, 4-iodo-1,1′-biphenyl, and 4-iodoanisole produced the corresponding sulfonylated compounds of 2b, 2c, and 2d in 65, 67, and 62% yields, respectively. Heteroaromatic iodides such as 2-iodopyridine, 3-iodopyridine, and 2-iodopyrazine afforded the corresponding sulfonylated compounds of 2e, 2f, and 2 g in 70, 64, and 71% yields, respectively. However, iodobenzene and iodotoluene did not provide the desired products under these optimized conditions. It is noteworthy that 4-bromoacetopheone and 4-chloroacetophenone also provided 2a in 55% and 22% yields, respectively. Next, we employed various electrophiles as counterparts in the coupling reactions conducted using 4-iodoacetophenone and thiourea dioxide (Scheme 4 ). First, 4-iodoacetophenone was reacted with thiourea dioxide under the optimized conditions, and the resulting mixture was treated with various electrophiles. As expected, the reaction with ethyl 2-bromoacetate produced the desired product, 3 in 76% yield. Treatment with methyl iodide, benzyl bromide, and allyl bromide resulted in the corresponding arylsulfonylated compounds of 4, 5, and 6 in 54, 58, and 71% yields, respectively. When the reaction was conducted using 2-chlorobenzothiazole as the electrophile at 100 °C for 1.5 h, the desired sulfonyl product, 7 was formed in 62% yield. When the sulfinate intermediate was treated with an aqueous solution, the corresponding aryl sulfonic acid 8 was formed in 74% yield. To study the reaction mechanism in detail, several control experiments were conducted using 1a, thiourea dioxide, and tert‑butyl 2-bromoacetate as standard substrates (see Table 2 ). For comparison, a copper oxide-doped graphitic carbon nitride (Cu2O-g-C3N4) sample was prepared and employed as the catalyst in a standard reaction. The Cu2O-g-C3N4 catalyst afforded 2a in 52% yield, which is lower than that obtained with our Cu(0)-g-C3N4 catalyst (entry 2). When pristine graphic carbon nitride (without copper) was used as the catalyst under photoirradiation conditions, 2a was formed in 24% yield (entry 3). In addition, we found that 2a was formed in 12% yield when the standard reaction using Cu(0)-g-C3N4 was conducted under dark conditions (entry 4). As discussed above, Cu(0)-g-C3N4 had significantly higher activity than Cu2O-g-C3N4 in three-component arylsulfonylation. We speculate that the photoredox reaction in the presence of these two catalysts proceeds in different ways owing the different electronic states of Cu(0) and Cu2O. In the case of Cu(0)-g-C3N4, photo-induced electrons move freely to the conduction band of Cu(0) to participate in the reduction reaction, while the holes at g-C3N4 nanosheets react with the substrate. On the other hand, as the conducting band of Cu2O is located at a relatively higher position compared to that of g-C3N4 nanosheets, in the case of Cu2O-g-C3N4, the hole is expected to move to the valence band of Cu2O, while the electron remains in g-C3N4. Even in this case, the reaction may proceed at each of the two catalytic sites. However, the electron movement is limited at g-C3N4 nanosheets, a semiconductor with a conductivity of 10−5 to 10−3 S cm−1 [29], resulting in lower reduction capacity compared to that of metallic Cu(0) nanoclusters. When pristine g-C3N4 nanosheets was used, the product yield was significantly lower; this is probably because the catalyst state is not appropriate for the mechanism by which both electrons and holes react with the corresponding substrate owing to the fast recombination of the photogenerated excitons. The significantly lower yield obtained in the reaction conducted in the dark state using our catalyst (Table 2, entry 4) clearly suggests that the reaction by the dual catalytic activity of Cu(0)-g-C3N4 proceeded as the major route of the coupling reaction. To evaluate the potential recyclability of Cu(0)-g-C3N4, the reaction of 1a, thiourea dioxide, and tert‑butyl 2-bromoacetate was conducted under standard conditions using the recycled catalyst. After completing the catalyzed reaction, the organic products were extracted with ethyl acetate and the yield of 2a was determined by gas chromatography using a standard. The solid precipitate in the aqueous phase was washed thrice with DMSO and dried in vacuum. The recovered Cu(0)-g-C3N4 was transferred to a new reaction vial with fresh reagents, and the reaction was conducted again under standard conditions. When this process was repeated ten times as shown in Fig. 4 , the reaction yield remained unchanged. 3 Conclusions A Cu(0)-g-C3N4 nanocomposite was prepared and applied in coupling reactions in which the photo-induced excitons in g-C3N4 nanosheets were utilized. In the Cu(0)-g-C3N4 catalyst, 2–5 nm Cu(0) nanoclusters are bound to g-C3N4 nanosheets at several nanometer interparticle spacings, and the catalyst exhibits good photoredox catalytic activity in the three-component reaction of aryl iodide, thiourea dioxide, and tert‑butyl 2-bromoacetate, affording the desired arylsulfones in good yields. In addition, this catalytic system exhibits good catalytic activity when used with various electrophiles such as ethyl 2-bromoacetate, methyl iodide, benzyl bromide, allyl bromide, 2-chlorobenzothiazole, and water, resulting in the production of the corresponding arylsulfonyl compounds in good yields. The high reaction yields obtained under the catalysis of Cu(0)-g-C3N4 indicate that the intended exciton separation and accumulation of electrons and holes in Cu(0) and g-C3N4 nanosheets, respectively, occurred during the reaction, resulting in the reduction of arylhalide at the Cu(0) site and the oxidation of the sulfur dioxide anion at the g-C3N4 nanosheets site for the coupling of components to generate arylsulfones in a single pot. This is the first report on heterogeneous photocatalytic arylsulfonylation and the demonstration of a catalytic system exhibiting dual catalytic activity through reduction and oxidation pathways in the coupling reaction. Above all, excellent catalyst recyclability up to 10 times was shown, and eco-friendly reaction conditions such as reactants, solvents, and by-products were obtained. This catalytic method may be applied in various coupling reactions, including photoredox reactions CRediT authorship contribution statement Jinseok Lee, Seunghwan An, Hyun Min Jung, and Sunwoo Lee conceived and designed the experiments. coredata.dc:description: A photocatalytic system of Cu(0) nanocluster-bound graphitic carbon nitride (Cu(0)-g-C3N4) was developed for three-component arylsulfonylation reactions. The Cu(0)-g-C3N4 nanocomposite has a structure in which 2–5 nm metallic Cu nanoclusters are anchored on the surface of g-C3N4 nanosheets. The Cu(0) clusters were synthesized by reducing Cu2+ ions with ascorbic acid in the presence of g-C3N4 nanosheets. Cu(0)-g-C3N4 was designed to exhibit dual catalytic activity involving the transfer of photo-induced electrons from g-C3N4 to Cu(0) for the reduction of arylhalides, while the holes in g-C3N4 oxidize the sulfur dioxide anion. The structure of the catalyst was confirmed by electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The well-defined, air-stable Cu(0)-g-C3N4 catalyst effectively promotes the sulfonylation of aryl iodides, thiourea dioxide, and electrophiles to afford the corresponding arylsulfonyl compounds in moderate to good yields. The reusability of the catalyst was also evaluated, and it could be reused up to ten times in arylsulfonylation without the loss of its activity.
coredata.dc:title: Recyclable and dual active catalyst of copper nanocluster-bound graphitic carbon nitride for the photo-induced synthesis of arylsulfones
